aliases.name: Poltergeist
aliases.meaning: Noisy ghost or spirit - from 'poltern' (to make noise) and 'geist' (ghost/spirit)

description.summary: A phenomenon characterized by physical disturbances including object movement, unexplained sounds, and occasional violence, often centered around a specific individual, typically an adolescent. Distinguished from traditional hauntings by its kinetic and interactive nature.
description.full: Poltergeist phenomena represent one of the most dramatic forms of alleged paranormal activity, characterized by physical disturbances that include objects moving or being thrown, loud unexplained noises (knocks, raps, bangs), electrical disturbances, temperature fluctuations, and in rare cases physical attacks on witnesses. Unlike traditional hauntings attributed to spirits of the deceased, poltergeist activity typically centers around a specific living person—most commonly an adolescent experiencing emotional or psychological stress. The phenomenon often begins gradually, escalates over weeks or months, and then ceases abruptly. Cases have been documented since ancient times and continue to be reported globally. Explanations range from paranormal (disembodied spirits, demonic entities) to parapsychological (unconscious psychokinesis by the focal person) to skeptical (fraud, misinterpretation, natural causes). The term comes from German 'poltern' (to make noise) and 'geist' (ghost/spirit).

etymology.origin: German compound word first appearing in folklore in the 16th century
etymology.meaning: Noisy ghost or spirit - 'poltern' (to make noise, rumble, crash) + 'geist' (ghost, spirit)
etymology.first_use: Early modern German folklore; entered English in 19th century

behavioral_patterns.onset: Usually gradual, beginning with minor disturbances
behavioral_patterns.progression: Typically escalates over days, weeks, or months
behavioral_patterns.duration: Usually 2-6 months; can last days to years in extreme cases
behavioral_patterns.activity_period: Can occur any time; some cases show nocturnal preference
behavioral_patterns.focus: Centers on specific person (agent/focus) in 90% of cases
behavioral_patterns.intelligence: Sometimes appears to respond to requests or show purposeful behavior; other times seems random
behavioral_patterns.communication: Some cases involve rapping answers to questions, moving objects to spell words, or voice phenomena

agent_characteristics.description: The focal person around whom poltergeist activity centers
common_traits: Female more often than male (though both occur)
Family conflict or tension in home environment
Repressed emotions or inability to express feelings
History of trauma or abuse (in some cases)
Often unaware of being the focus initially
agent_characteristics.age_distribution: Peak incidence ages 12-15; can occur at any age but rare in adults without adolescents present
agent_characteristics.awareness: Agent typically unaware they are causing phenomena; unconscious if RSPK theory correct

range.description: Universal phenomenon reported across all cultures and time periods, though concentrated in areas with strong paranormal belief systems and active investigation communities.
countries: All countries; particularly well-documented in UK, USA, Germany, Japan, Brazil
regions: Global distribution with no geographic pattern

first_recorded.source: Roman and Chinese historical accounts describe poltergeist-like phenomena

Systematic parapsychological investigation; RSPK theory developed
Cases continue to be reported; increased skeptical scrutiny and hoax exposure

origins.cultural_roots: Poltergeist-like phenomena appear in folklore and historical records worldwide. Ancient Chinese, Roman, and medieval European sources describe disturbances matching modern poltergeist descriptions. The German term entered English vocabulary in 19th century.
origins.earliest_accounts: Ancient Rome: Pliny the Younger and others described household disturbances. Medieval records document numerous cases attributed to demons or spirits. First systematic documentation in early modern period.
origins.folklore_connections: Connected to mischievous spirits, household demons (like brownies, boggarts), and malevolent entities across cultures. Japanese 'tsukumogami', Chinese 'gui', and European fairy traditions share characteristics.

Famous English case investigated by Joseph Glanvill; knockings, drumming sounds, object movement

Famous Tennessee case involving Bell family; physical attacks, voices, death attributed to entity

history.modern_era: Poltergeist reports continue worldwide, though increased surveillance technology and skeptical scrutiny have led to exposure of many frauds. Parapsychologists continue to investigate cases using RSPK framework. Skeptics attribute phenomena to normal causes, fraud, or psychological factors. Cases remain controversial with no scientific consensus.

notable_cases.name: Enfield Poltergeist
notable_cases.description: The Enfield Poltergeist is one of the most famous and extensively documented poltergeist cases in history. Activity centered on the Hodgson family, particularly daughters Janet (11) and Margaret (13), in their council house in Enfield, North London. Phenomena included furniture moving on its own, objects being thrown, knockings and rappings, apparitions, physical assaults, fires starting, water puddles appearing, cold breezes, disembodied voices (including the gruff voice of 'Bill' speaking through Janet), and alleged levitations. Police constable Carolyn Heeps witnessed a chair sliding across the floor. Maurice Grosse and Guy Lyon Playfair of the Society for Psychical Research investigated for 18 months, documenting over 1,500 incidents. The case garnered extensive media coverage. While some incidents were admitted as pranks by Janet and Margaret (particularly levitation photographs), investigators believed the majority of phenomena were genuine. The case remains highly controversial.
phenomena: Levitations (some admitted as hoaxed, others disputed)

agent.name: Janet Hodgson
agent.characteristics: Adolescent girl; parents recently separated; under stress; some evidence of attention-seeking behavior but also genuine distress

evidence: Police testimony (PC Carolyn Heeps witnessed chair movement)

investigation.conclusion: Investigators concluded genuine paranormal activity occurred alongside some deliberate trickery by children

hoax_evidence: Janet and Margaret admitted faking some levitations
Caught bending spoons and other tricks
skeptical_analysis.investigator_response: Grosse and Playfair acknowledged pranks but maintained many incidents could not be explained by trickery given observation conditions

factors: Some phenomena admitted as hoaxes reduces credibility
credibility.notes: One of most documented cases; remains controversial due to mixed genuine/hoaxed phenomena

notable_cases.cultural_impact: Inspired books, documentaries, and films including 'The Conjuring 2' (2016); remains most famous poltergeist case
sources: Playfair, G.L. (1980). This House Is Haunted

notable_cases.name: Rosenheim Poltergeist

location.description: Law office of Sigmund Adam, Rosenheim, Bavaria

notable_cases.description: The Rosenheim Poltergeist case is notable for its extensive scientific investigation and focus on electrical phenomena. Activity occurred in a law office in Bavaria, centered on 19-year-old secretary Annemarie Schneider. Phenomena included telephones ringing without calls, massive unexplained phone bills (to speaking clock), light bulbs exploding or unscrewing, electrical meters spinning wildly, fluorescent lights swinging, power surges, and developing fluid in photocopiers being displaced. Physics professor Friedbert Karger and parapsychologist Hans Bender conducted extensive investigation, installing monitoring equipment. Phenomena only occurred during office hours when Annemarie was present and ceased when she left employment. Electrical engineers from utility company found no normal explanation. Annemarie was reportedly unhappy in her job and experiencing psychological stress. The case is considered one of the best-documented poltergeist cases with scientific investigation.
phenomena: Phone calls to speaking clock (600+ times)
Electrical meters spinning without power draw

agent.name: Annemarie Schneider
agent.characteristics: Young secretary; unhappy with job; emotionally stressed; phenomena ceased when she left employment

investigation.organization: Institute for Border Areas of Psychology (Freiburg)
investigation.conclusion: No conventional explanation found; attributed to RSPK centered on Annemarie

credibility.notes: Considered one of best-documented cases due to scientific rigor of investigation

sources: Bender, H. (1969). 'Modern Poltergeist Research' in Proceedings of the Parapsychological Association
Karger, F. & Zicha, G. (1968). Physical Investigation of Psychokinetic Phenomena in Rosenheim

notable_cases.name: Bell Witch

location.description: John Bell farm, Red River community, Robertson County

notable_cases.description: The Bell Witch is one of America's most famous poltergeist cases, occurring on the farm of John Bell in Tennessee. The entity called itself 'Kate' and communicated through disembodied voices. Phenomena included object movement, physical attacks (particularly against John Bell and daughter Betsy), apparitions, voices conversing with witnesses, prophecies, and singing. The entity claimed to be the spirit of Kate Batts, a neighbor. Activity escalated over four years, with the entity demonstrating knowledge of events happening elsewhere and speaking in multiple voices simultaneously. John Bell's death in 1820 was attributed to poison allegedly administered by the entity. The witch claimed responsibility and promised to return in 107 years. The case gained regional fame and was investigated by numerous witnesses. While impossible to verify details from accounts written decades later, the case became American folklore and inspired numerous books and films.
phenomena: Physical attacks (slapping, hair pulling, needle sticks)
Prophecies and knowledge of distant events
Death of John Bell (allegedly poisoned by entity)

agent.name: Betsy Bell
agent.characteristics: Adolescent daughter of John Bell; primary target of some phenomena; activity decreased after her engagement was broken

factors: Most accounts written decades after events
credibility.notes: Historical distance makes verification impossible; became legendary but core events may have occurred

notable_cases.cultural_impact: Most famous American poltergeist case; inspired numerous books, films, and tourist industry in Tennessee
sources: Ingram, M.V. (1894). An Authenticated History of the Bell Witch
Bell, Charles (1985). The Bell Witch: A Mysterious Spirit

notable_cases.name: Amityville Horror

credibility_factors: Limited - family only witnesses to most events

notable_cases.description: The Amityville Horror case became one of the most famous and controversial alleged hauntings in American history, though it is widely considered a hoax. The Lutz family claimed to experience terrifying paranormal activity during 28 days in their new home—the site of the DeFeo family murders a year earlier. Claimed phenomena included slime oozing from walls and ceilings, swarms of flies in winter, cold spots, foul odors, moving furniture, slamming doors, demonic apparitions (particularly a pig-like creature with red eyes), personality changes in George Lutz, and a room that remained unnaturally cold. The Warrens investigated and supported the claims. However, subsequent investigation revealed extensive evidence of fabrication: lawyer William Weber (representing Ronald DeFeo, the murderer) admitted helping the Lutzes concoct the story over wine; neighbors reported no disturbances; the Lutzes' own priest disputed their account; polygraph tests were failed or avoided; and the story changed in multiple retellings. Despite being discredited, the case became a cultural phenomenon spawning books, films, and sequels.

investigation.conclusion: Widely regarded as hoax for financial gain; multiple investigators concluded fraud

credibility.notes: Considered one of most famous paranormal hoaxes; included despite fraud as cautionary example and cultural phenomenon

notable_cases.cultural_impact: Massive: bestselling book (1977), blockbuster film (1979), numerous sequels, became archetypal haunted house story despite being fraud
sources: Kaplan, S. (1995). The Amityville Horror Conspiracy
notable_cases.warning: This case is widely discredited as a hoax. Included for historical and cultural significance.

notable_cases.name: Borley Rectory
notable_cases.description: Borley Rectory was dubbed 'the most haunted house in England' by paranormal investigator Harry Price. Built in 1863, the rectory experienced decades of reported phenomena including phantom nun sightings, unexplained footsteps, bells ringing, wall writing, object movement, phantom coach, and poltergeist activity. Multiple residents reported phenomena. Harry Price conducted extensive investigation from 1929-1938, claiming to document paranormal activity. The rectory burned down in 1939 under mysterious circumstances. However, subsequent analysis by SPR investigators revealed Price had likely exaggerated, misrepresented, and possibly fabricated evidence. Some witnesses recanted testimony, and much of Price's evidence was questioned. While some genuinely unexplained incidents may have occurred, the case is now viewed as heavily contaminated by fraud and embellishment.

investigation.conclusion: Price's claims largely discredited by SPR; significant fraud suspected; some genuine phenomena possible but unverifiable

factors: Some core incidents may be genuine but unknowable
credibility.notes: Famous case significantly undermined by fraud revelations; cautionary tale about investigator bias

sources: Price, H. (1940). The Most Haunted House in England (disputed)
Dingwall, E.J., et al. (1956). The Haunting of Borley Rectory (SPR critical report)

paranormal.name: Disembodied Spirit Theory
paranormal.description: Poltergeist activity is caused by the spirit of a deceased person, often one who died traumatically or has unfinished business. The spirit manipulates physical objects to communicate or express anger.
criticisms: Doesn't explain agent-focused pattern
No scientific evidence for survival after death
Many cases have no identified deceased person

paranormal.name: Demonic/Inhuman Entity Theory
paranormal.description: Activity is caused by non-human malevolent entities (demons, negative spirits) that may target vulnerable individuals, particularly adolescents.
proponents: Religious investigators like Ed and Lorraine Warren
evidence_cited: Cases with religious significance (attacks on religious items)
criticisms: Based on religious belief rather than evidence
Same phenomena occur across cultures with different belief systems
Psychological explanations more parsimonious
Religious intervention success may be placebo effect

paranormal.name: Elemental/Nature Spirit Theory
paranormal.description: Some poltergeist activity attributed to elemental spirits or nature entities disturbed by human activity or construction.
evidence_cited: Cases involving new construction or land disturbance
criticisms: No evidence for such entities
Culturally specific interpretation
Doesn't explain agent-focused pattern

parapsychological.name: RSPK - Recurrent Spontaneous Psychokinesis
parapsychological.description: The leading parapsychological theory, developed by William G. Roll. Poltergeist phenomena are unconscious psychokinetic (PK) effects produced by a living agent (focus person), typically an adolescent under psychological or emotional stress. The agent unknowingly causes physical effects through mental processes during periods of emotional turmoil, repressed anger, or stress. Activity is a manifestation of internal psychological conflict.
evidence_cited: Strong correlation with adolescent focal person (90% of cases)
Correlation with psychological stress, family conflict
Activity follows agent from location to location
Ceases when agent's stress resolves or agent matures
Phenomena occur in agent's presence or proximity
supporting_research: Roll's investigation of 116 cases found agent in 92%
Psychological testing of agents shows higher stress
mechanisms_proposed: Conversion of psychological stress to physical energy
criticisms: Psychokinesis not scientifically established
Mechanism unexplained
Some phenomena occur outside agent's presence
Doesn't explain intelligent communication in some cases
No repeatable laboratory demonstration

psychological.name: Pubescent Stress Manifestation
psychological.description: Poltergeist phenomena are entirely psychological—a combination of unconscious fraud, attention-seeking behavior, and family dynamics involving stressed adolescents. The adolescent (often unknowingly) creates phenomena through natural means (trickery) to express distress, gain attention, or exert control in troubled family situations.
evidence_cited: Phenomena stop when agent is continuously observed
Phenomena fit psychological profile of stress expression
criticisms: Doesn't explain all witnessed phenomena
Some events occur with continuous observation
Multiple independent witnesses in some cases
Some phenomena beyond apparent ability of agent to fake

psychological.name: Mass Hysteria/Suggestion
psychological.description: Group suggestibility and mass psychogenic illness cause witnesses to misinterpret normal events or experience shared delusions. Expectation creates perception of paranormal activity where none exists.
evidence_cited: Contagion of belief in affected households
Witnesses' accounts become more dramatic over time
criticisms: Doesn't explain physical evidence (objects moved, damage)
Some cases have single initial witness
Independent witnesses from outside household

skeptical.name: Fraud and Hoax
skeptical.description: Most or all poltergeist cases are deliberate hoaxes perpetrated for attention, fame, or financial gain. The agent (often a child or adolescent) deliberately creates phenomena through tricks, sometimes with adult complicity.
evidence_cited: Numerous proven hoaxes (Fox Sisters, Amityville, etc.)
Simple tricks can create impressive effects
known_techniques: Taking advantage of investigation equipment limitations
examples: Enfield children caught faking some phenomena
criticisms: Doesn't explain all cases satisfactorily
Some phenomena witnessed by credible observers under conditions preventing trickery
Assumes all cases fraudulent without individual examination
Some agents appear genuinely distressed rather than deceptive

skeptical.name: Misinterpretation of Normal Events
skeptical.description: Natural phenomena (house settling, animals, plumbing issues, electrical problems, etc.) are misinterpreted as paranormal, especially in context of belief or expectation.
evidence_cited: Houses naturally make sounds (settling, pipes, etc.)
Electrical issues common in older buildings
criticisms: Doesn't account for dramatic, witnessed phenomena
Doesn't explain agent-specific pattern
Some cases professionally investigated ruling out normal causes

skeptical.name: Investigator Fraud/Bias
skeptical.description: In some cases, paranormal investigators themselves fabricate or exaggerate evidence due to belief, desire for fame, or financial incentives.
evidence_cited: Harry Price and Borley Rectory fabrications
Ed and Lorraine Warren's credibility issues
Lack of proper controls in investigations
examples: Harry Price's methods at Borley questioned
Book deals and media careers as motives

key_findings: Approximately 90% of poltergeist cases involve an identifiable agent/focus person
Peak age for agents is 12-15 years (puberty/adolescence)
Strong correlation with psychological stress, family conflict, and emotional turmoil
Female agents slightly more common than male, though both occur
Cases typically last 2-6 months before ceasing spontaneously
Phenomena often follow agent to new locations
Activity usually ceases when agent matures or stress resolves
Most cases have mixture of genuine puzzling phenomena and proven trickery
Significant number of proven hoaxes and frauds
No repeatable laboratory demonstration of poltergeist phenomena
No scientifically verified evidence of paranormal causation
research.ongoing_studies: Contemporary research focuses on psychological profiling of agents, neurological factors (temporal lobe activity), environmental factors (EMF, infrasound), and case documentation with modern technology. Skeptical research emphasizes fraud detection and natural explanations.

investigation.warning: Poltergeist investigation can be dangerous due to potential for physical harm (thrown objects, fires). Psychological well-being of focal person (often a child) must be prioritized. Many cases involve fraud, and investigators should maintain critical perspective.

identification.description: Determining if case is genuine poltergeist phenomenon vs. normal causes or fraud
criteria: Correlation between phenomena and focal person's presence
Psychological stress in focal person or family
Rule out normal explanations (plumbing, animals, structural issues)
Rule out fraud through observation and controls

investigation_methods.description: Maintain presence and observe phenomena directly; note correlation with agent's location and state
investigation_methods.purpose: Document phenomena and determine if trickery possible

investigation_methods.description: Test if phenomena occur under controlled conditions preventing trickery
investigation_methods.purpose: Determine if phenomena genuine or hoaxed

investigation_methods.description: Evaluate focal person's psychological state, family dynamics
investigation_methods.purpose: Understand agent's stress factors and mental state; identify RSPK correlation

investigation_methods.description: Document accounts from all witnesses separately

ethical_considerations: Protect focal person (often minor) from exploitation
Don't validate delusions if mental illness present
Involve mental health professionals when appropriate
red_flags_for_fraud: Phenomena only occur when focal person alone

traditions: English folklore (brownies, boggarts - mischievous house spirits)
folklore.beliefs: Poltergeist-like phenomena attributed to various entities across cultures: mischievous spirits, angered ghosts, demons, fairies, or nature spirits. Often seen as punishment for wrongdoing, disturbance of burial sites, or result of curse. Protection rituals common.
folklore.cross_cultural_patterns: Similar phenomena reported across unrelated cultures suggest either genuine phenomenon or universal psychological/social patterns

religious_perspectives.view: Often interpreted as demonic activity; exorcism may be performed; some traditions recognize distinction from possession
